messages: 57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (00:37): random question...anyone know the history behind percentage sizes in standards mode? specifically, in quirks mode, to resolve a percentage, you walk up the tree until you hit the first non-auto, non-percentage valu (roughly)...for standards mode, if you hit an auto value you bail.
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (00:37): this behavior seems totally wrong to me and i'm wondering how the decision got made, so i can propose a fix for the future
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (00:38): 104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01: ^^^ maybe you know?
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:38): which behavior seems wrong?
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:38): quirks or standards?
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (00:38): 104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01: standards
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (00:39): 104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01: right or wrong is irrelevant...it's clearly not what people want/expect
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:39): it's what the spec says, and I suppose we've never argued
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (00:39): it mgiht be a compat problem now, though
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (00:39): 104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01: oh yeah...no way we can change it
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (00:39): 104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01: but, if there wasn't a good reason for it, we could always add a new unit
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (00:40): 104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01: the way you get the behavior you want these days is to have to put height 100% on every ancestor including the html element
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (00:40): 104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01: == the suck
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (00:40): 104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01: web dev after web dev is confused by this and it sucks to have to litter your tree with height values
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (00:41): 104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01: hwen you change your structure a little, you have to remember to put height 100% on any new elements you add

57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (00:57): 104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01: a coworker had an interesting idea of an altnerative to a new unit, we could add a new property a la box-sizing to control the behavior in a subtree
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:09): 57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 - what's the use case you're trying to address?
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:10): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: making an element fill one of it's ancestors...which is very common...e.g.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:10): 57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 - doesn't flexbox solve that?
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:10): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: making a UI that fills the whole viewport, making a dialog whose contents fill the dialog
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:10): cc: TabAtkins
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:10): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: but the flexbox itself needs to fill it's container
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:11): 57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13, hmm, maybe position:absolute;left:0;top:0;right:0;bottom:0;height:auto;width:auto ?
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:12): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: yes, that works, but it's not at all intuitive and very few people learn to do it
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:12): yeah, it's copy-pasteo
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:13): but that should avoid the "you have to set height explicitly all the way down" thing right?
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:14): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: that also doesn't let you do non 100% sizes...whcih i realize i didn't list as a use-case just now...but is totally valid
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:14): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: e.g. if you want a split-pane view
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:15): left:0;right:50%; ‚Ä¶ left:50%;right:0
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:15): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: how do you resolve the 50%?
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:15): wait
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:15): i'm confused
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:15): yeah...how do you resolve right:50%?
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:15): positions are inset from the respective edges
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:15): isn't that the same problem?
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:15): 50% of what?
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:15): no it works like you want it
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:18): wth...i can't believe percentage for width/height is resolved totally differently from left/right
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:18): i mean...i just tested it in webkit and it worked
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:18): but wth
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:19): that's even more broken
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:19): works in gecko too
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:19): sigh
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:20): 57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13, it's not totally broken
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:21): it's exactly what happens when we pursue a strategy like you were suggesting
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:21): to fix the situation
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:21): the latter technology "does the right thing"
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:21): improving on the legacy standards compat
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:21): oh i see...percentages work with position: absolute actually
57551cb51d38c51417f5abfeacfb9b13 (01:21): so height: 50% works fine if it's position:absolute
